statement:
Suppose $U$ is an open set in ${\mathbb{R}}^n$ and $f$ is a locally
integrable function on $U$, i.e.,
$f\in L^1_{\scriptsize{\mbox{loc}}}(U)$. Then the mapping
$$\begin{aligned}
T_f: {\mathcal{D}}(U) &\to& {\mathbb{C}}\\
     u      &\mapsto& \int_U f(x) u(x) dx\end{aligned}$$ is a zeroth
order distribution. (See parent entry for notation ${\mathcal{D}}(U)$.)

If $f$ and $g$ are both locally integrable functions on an open set $U$,
and $T_f=T_g$, then it follows (see ), that $f=g$ almost everywhere.
Thus, the mapping $f\mapsto T_f$ is a linear injection when
$L^1_{\scriptsize{\mbox{loc}}}$ is equipped with the usual equivalence
relation for an $L^p$-space. For this reason, one usually writes $f$ for
the distribution $T_f$.
names: every locally integrable function is a distribution
